companies.name: Vantage Resources
companies.description: Leading Australian mining company specializing in iron ore and coal extraction

questionnaire.name: Mining Operations Questionnaire
questionnaire.description: Comprehensive evaluation of mining operations across all critical areas
questionnaire.guidelines: Assess all aspects of mining operations including work management, defect elimination, asset strategy, and asset health

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Exceeds requirements with continuous improvement and leading practices

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Meets requirements with systematic and preventive approaches

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Basic systems exist but inconsistent execution, gaps in compliance

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Ad-hoc approaches, fire-fighting mode, immediate intervention required

questions.title: Work Identification Training
questions.question_text:
1. How are new employees being trained in Work Identification and Notification creation?
2. Have Operators (if applicable, e.g.. inspection routes) and Maintainers received Work Identification training?
3. Are there any training gaps in your organization regarding entering a work request into your SAP?
4. Have Service Providers / contractors received Work Identification training?
questions.context:
Work Identification Training
Operators / maintainers / Maint professionals / contractors receive training in Work Identification and Notification creation, considering:
• Work identification is incorporated into new employees training
• Sources of training materials may be:
o > Site-specific Work Identification training
o > Work Identification Awareness presentation
o > SAP raising notification training.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Training recipients identified but less than 25% trained.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Training recipients identified but less than 50% trained and most emergent work is incorrectly coded.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: 75% of people trained and most emergent work is correctly coded.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: 90% of people trained and all emergent work is correctly coded.

questions.title: Preventive Maintenance Work Setup
questions.question_text:
1. Is all of the PM Work set up within the SAP?
2. Is most of the PM work calendar-based, and/or based on OEM recommendations, rather than tactics reviews?
3. For new equipment, is PM Work  based on formal Asset Tactics Development?  What is the process for entering them into the SAP?
4.  What is the process for modifications to existing tactics, and entering them into the SAP? How often are formal reviews undertaken?
5. Preventative work orders are part of the maintenance regime (PM02)
questions.context:
Identification of PM work
PM Work has a defined scope and frequency, and originates from the asset maintenance strategy, and built into its maintenance tactics. The maintenance tactics are a set of activities carried out to enable the realisation of the defined reliability/availability of the Asset. All maintenance strategies and tactics are created within the SAP for automatic generation as PM01

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: PM Work captured in SAP; is either mostly calendar- based, and/or based on OEM recommendations, rather than tactics reviews. <50% of scheduled work is system generated.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: PM work is identified for new or critical equipment using a formal tactic review process e.g., FMEA, RCM or PMO. >50% of scheduled work is Corrective PM

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: PM work is being identified/modified using formal tactic review process but is not entered into the SAP system in a timely manner. >65% of scheduled work is PM

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: PM work is being identified/modified using formal tactic review process and is being entered into the SAP system in a timely manner. >80% of scheduled work is PM

questions.title: Operator Inspection Checklists
questions.question_text:
1. Are there Operators' checklists for all equipment? (Note this refers to inspection checklists, not merely pre-op inspection forms).
2. Is there alignment with the checklist details and the maintenance strategies? How are changes to inspection requirements and strategies transferred to the checklist?
3. All are all defects entered as Notifications in the SAP in a timely manner?
4. Do Notifications typically represent all aspects of the true condition of the equipment?
questions.context:
Inspection Checklist Design - Operators
Operator inspection checklists are up-to-date and aligned with equipment maintenance strategy. (Daily, Weekly, Monthly). Defects found as a result are entered in the SAP in a timely manner considering:
• Safety
• Materials
• Tasks including specification
• Additional Resources
• Feedback / comments field
• Sign off.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Checklists are poorly designed and incomplete and do not exist for all critical equipment. Operations verbally notify AM personnel.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Checklists are good quality and up to date but not using a standard design. Exist for all critical equipment. Operations Supv enter Notifications in SAP. Maintenance Supervisors approve Notifications for Work Order creation.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Checklists based on a standard template and exist for the majority of equipment. All Notifications are entered in the SAP.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Checklists periodically reviewed and exist for all equipment as identified through Asset Tactics Development.  All operations personnel enter Notifications in SAP, and reviewed for rejected or additional info, and resubmit as needed.

questions.title: Maintainer Inspection Checklists
questions.question_text:
1. When inspection checklists are performed by maintainers, are defects found entered in the SAP?
2. Is there alignment with the checklist details and the maintenance strategies?
3. How are changes to inspection requirements and strategies transferred to the checklist?
4. Are defects found as a result of inspections scheduled using the standard Maintenance Planning Process, or executed as part of "scheduled" work?
questions.context:
Inspection Checklist Design - Maintainers
Inspection checklists are up-to-date and aligned with equipment maintenance strategy. (Daily, Weekly, Monthly) considering:
• Safety
• Materials
• Tasks including specification
• Additional Resources
• Feedback / comments field
• Sign off.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Checklists are poorly designed and incomplete and do not exist for all critical equipment. Supervisors enter Notifications from maintainers input, or maintainers execute the work without consulting scheduler or supervisor.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Checklists are good quality and up to date but not using a standard design. They exist for all critical equipment.  Maintainers enter subsequent notifications and submit DE ideas.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Checklists based on a standard template and exist for the majority of equipment.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Checklists periodically reviewed and exist for all equipment as identified through Asset Tactics Development.

questions.title: Work Scoping Standards
questions.question_text:
1. Has the Company Maintenance Planning Process been communicated and made available to all?
2. Is current planning performed as per the Company Maintenance Planning Process?  As applicable, do job scopes include clean-up, decon requirements, and rotables information?
3. Parts availability is being verified before scheduling of tasks?
4. Are Tasks rejected which don't comply with current equipment tactics, or rescoped to align with Budget, Tactics, operations and or Equipment stability requirements?
questions.context:
Scoping Work
To ensure that the planning function is performed in the same manner all the time, well document planning standards for work orders and work management must be in place and followed:
• Workshop visits by planners during planning of major tasks
• Task frequencies and durations captured
• All resource, materials, shared equipment requirements captured
• Safety requirements determined and captured
• Validity of Task reviewed in relation to Tactics
• Additional documentation (checklists) attached

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Company guidelines for scoping work known about but not complied with Some Operations in Work Orders but not much detail.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Company guidelines for scoping work are established and followed. More detailed operations with >60% planning accuracy.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Planning standards comply with 80% of Company guidelines for scoping work. Good detail in operations >80% estimate accuracy.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Planning standards fully compliant with the Company Maintenance Planning Process. Very well detailed operations with >90% estimate accuracy.

questions.title: Long Term Planning Horizons
questions.question_text:
1. Long Term Planning (LTP) develops plans for Preventative and Capital work >26 weeks
2. Depot Planning receives handover from LTP and is responsible within 26 weeks for Preventative, Corrective and all other work order types until handover to Depot Scheduler at 3 weeks
3. LTP and Capital Planner is responsible within 26 weeks for Capital Work
4. Handover from LTP to Depot Planner occurs at 26 weeks on a rolling monthly basis
questions.context:
Long Term Planning Horizons & Tasks
Capital Planning tasks are managed by Long Term Planning (26 weeks to 3 weeks).  Clear differentation of maintenance tasks required to assign maintenance planner form Asset Managament & Startegy or Business Unit.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Guidance for delineation of tasks between LTP and BU is defined but not followed.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Guidance for delineation of tasks between LTP and BU is defined and followed >50%.  Communication channels between LTP and BU is established and LTP raises issues with BU when required.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Guidance for delineation of tasks between LTP and BU is defined and followed >80%, including adhering to time horizons.  LTP is actively engaged with BU on a monthly basis.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Guidance for delineation of tasks between LTP and BU is defined and followed >90%.  LTP is actively engaged with BU.

questions.title: Task Lists and Standard Jobs
questions.question_text:
1. How many task lists are available?  What % of work (PM, corrective & breakdown) is created from task lists or standard jobs?
2. Are the task lists that are available used including ordering of required material for jobs?
3. Is there are formal process to update and create new tasks lists?
4. Are task list instructions detailed with specification or are they "Is motor hot?" or "Check Alignment"?
questions.context:
Task List / Standard Jobs
To reduce the amount of work, and support continuous improvement, standard jobs or task lists should be used during the planning process.
A Job should only ever be planned once, saved as a task list or standard job, and then improved over time.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Task Lists or Standard Jobs have only been developed for and are only used for PM's (Not Corrective or Breakdown).

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Task Lists are developed and used for all PM's and >50% for Corrective Rotable Work Orders PM/Corrective/ZPM6.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Task Lists are developed as required and used for all PM's and >75% for Corrective & Rotable Work Orders PM/Corrective/ZPM6.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Task Lists are developed and used for all tasks. Note - except one off tasks that will not be done again.

questions.title: Backlog and Forward Log Management
questions.question_text:
1. Is the concept of backlog, forward log and future log understood?
2. Does the forward log reflect the actual next available down-time condition of the equipment?
3. How often is the backlog being managed and by whom?
4. Is equipment criticality taken into consideration during the Planning process and workload reviews?
questions.context:
Backlog / Forward Log Work Management
To enable effective loading of scheduled maintenance tasks, the Workload must be consistently updated, accurate, and include:
• No duplicate tasks and no standing work orders
• Resource requirements including contractors and support equipment
• Task durations
• Intended start date, in the future
• Priorities set.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Planners and supervisors manage when time allows.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Planners and supervisors are managing weekly.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Planners and supervisors are managing daily. No evidence of duplicate and outdated work orders and/or notifications.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Backlog reviewed weekly at the weekly Draft Schedule mtg. Outstanding notifications and work orders may require a group decisions to delete based on equipment criticality and safety implications.

questions.title: Long-Term Scheduling Horizons
questions.question_text:
1. How far in the future is the rough-cut schedule developed and documented?
2. Is the rough-cut schedule regularly reviewed with Operations? How far in the future?
3. Does the rough-cut schedule take the operations schedule into account ?
4. Are there any measures in place or reporting undertaken to ensure this process is followed?
Is the long-term planning horizon long enough to allow for effective resource planning and an integrated maintenance and operations plan?
questions.context:
Long Term Scheduling Time Horizons 
Long term, rough-cut schedules must be developed to assist with budgeting and co-coordinating of major maintenance shutdowns and other significant events affecting operations planning and consider:
• Rough-cut capacity scheduling is a key element of forward log maintenance planning
• Maintenance and operations schedules are integrated

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Forward log rough-cut capacity planning to 6 months in the future is in place to determine resource needs.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Forward log rough-cut capacity planning to 12 months in the future is in place to determine resource needs and is also reviewed with Operations.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Forward log rough-cut capacity planning to 24 months in the future is in place to determine resource needs and is also reviewed with Operations and aligned with the 12 month Operations plan.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Forward log rough-cut capacity planning to 5 years in the future is in place to determine resource needs and is also reviewed with operations. There is an integrated Maintenance and Operations plan for 24 months into the future which is regularly reviewed.

questions.title: Resource Capacity Management
questions.question_text:
1. How are non-maintenance activities (training) managed?  Are there any standing work orders used for scheduling?
2. Is there a formal process for forecasting and reviewing the need for additional resources?
3. Are the work centre capacities (available man-hours) managed weekly for internal resources and alliance contractors?
4. Is system functionality for resource tracking used to its fullest extent?
questions.context:
Available Resources
Effective scheduling of work requires control of resources including contractors utilising the following:
• Leave guidelines
• Training guidelines and/or competencies
• Use of available system functionality (preferable),
• Use of manual resource tracking tool
• Alliance contractor work centres are set-up and managed

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Scheduling for depot/P&E maintainers and limited alliance contractor scheduling.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Scheduling for depot/P&E maintainers and improved contractor scheduling; Tasks are scheduled to the day and the work centre.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Scheduling for all depot/P&E maintainers, contractors, and shared equipment; Tasks are scheduled to the day, the work centre and the individual, using network functionality as required. Scheduling to the hour, not just to the day.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Scheduling for all depot/P&E maintainers, contractors, and shared equipment; Tasks are scheduled to the day, the work centre and the individual, using network functionality as required.

questions.title: Resource Loading and Utilization
questions.question_text:
1. Are the guidelines determined and documented?  Have these been communicated and aligned with current metrics?
2.  Does the amount of people available drive what work is scheduled, rather than what work is required drives determines how many resources are scheduled?
3. Is work order resource planning adequate to enable scheduling of available resources?
4. What percent of available resources are scheduled on a weekly basis?
5. Is reporting on Resource Utilization and Use of Resource Availability reviewed regularly?
questions.context:
Schedule Resource Loading
Some guidelines for effective utilization of all resources must be communicated and followed and include:
• No standing work orders used
• Loading per person per week in hours
• Non-maintenance activities are deducted from available hours
• Work centre resource management
• Review of KPI's to determine proper schedule loading

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Guidelines and targets have been set but not used; Limited resource tracking using SAP or manual resource tracking tool e.g., Excel, Access etc. Only internal resources tracked.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Scheduled hours are consistently below targets as established in the guidelines; Resource tracking using SAP but not always current due to changes (training, adhoc leave etc. not always being updated.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Scheduled hours are consistently scheduled within + or 5% of objective; Resource tracking using SAP, which is used by scheduler and generally accurate. External resources also tracked in the SAP. >80% Schedule Loading for all resources.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Scheduled hours are consistently scheduled within 0 or - 5% of target. There is a controlled process for increasing the scheduled resource loading percentage; Precision resource tracking using system functionality, which is used by scheduler.

questions.title: Scheduling Review Meetings
questions.question_text:
1. Are there a regular scheduling meetings?
2. Do the right people attend?
3. Is the scheduling meeting agenda followed, is there a meeting chair and are minutes taken for distribution?
4. Are improvement actions being assigned weekly? Is there an Actions Log?
questions.context:
Scheduling Review/Lock in Meetings
There should be formal 'schedule' meetings.
• Operations and maintenance sit down to discuss the proposed schedule. This is done in tandem with the operations schedule. Any active discussions regarding schedule inclusions should happen at this meeting.
• The teams get back together to formally lock down the schedule. This discussion should be a formality and should rarely involve disagreements on the schedule inclusions. The timing of the second meeting is usually dictated by the lock-down date in the SAP.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: There are formal schedule meeting agendas. They are not always followed and there are no minutes or actions logs kept. Operations are not invited. Not all required maintenance people always attend the meetings.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Agendas are followed. Minutes and action logs are kept. Maintenance invitees always attend or send a delegate. Operations are invited but do not always attend.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Minutes and action logs are always updated and shared with all meeting attendees. All of the right roles from Operations and maintenance usually attend the meetings. Key KPI's, non- conformances and incomplete operations discussed.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: All of the right roles from Operations and maintenance always attend the meetings. Managers randomly attend to demonstrate support and the importance of the meetings.

questions.title: Shift Handover and Communication
questions.question_text:
1. Are critical jobs and/or tasks handled differently?
2. Are additional faults/defects identified during the course of work not completed due to lack of communications between shifts?
3. Are delay causes identified and relayed to oncoming crews?
4. How well prepared are the oncoming crew members when they leave their shift start briefing?
5. Are improvement actions captured during the shift start meetings?
questions.context:
Daily Shift Start / Shift Handover
To create awareness for oncoming crews an effective handover / turnover process must be in place and address the following:
• Participated by all relevant personnel
• Current progress on planned work
• Possible operations requirements during shift
• Causes for delays, if any
• Changes in environment / risks
• Additional faults / defects found
• Work packages handed out and reviewed as required

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description:
The crews gather for pre-shift briefings but all information is given verbally.
Supervisors exchange handover information verbally.
No equipment or MBP KPI's are discussed.
Major SHE issues or events mentioned.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description:
Supervisors use checklists and/or shift logs & discuss scheduled, urgent  and backlog WO's.
Maintainers are provided with Work Packs at shift start, these are not discussed in any detail.
KPI's are discussed only when instructed by senior leader.
Relevant SHE issues discussed.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description:
Supervisors use the SAP to review all unscheduled and scheduled Work.
Any non-routine work is discussed in detail. Standard KPI's are reviewed.
operations issues discussed. Visual boards used and always up to date.
Supervisors run the pre-shift briefing. Maintainers share the task of running the pre-shift briefing.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description:
Innovative ways have been introduced to ensure all work is understood at the start of shift and handed over to the oncoming shift. Additional KPI's are reviewed when relevant to the team.
Maintainers share the task of running the pre-shift briefing.

questions.title: Equipment Handover and Release
questions.question_text:
1. Does the operator have the ability to refuse acceptance of  equipment?
2. Does Operations often insist on equipment release prior to completion of maintenance activities?
3. How often does equipment fail shortly after a maintenance intervention?
4. Is there timely operator acceptance of equipment?
questions.context:
Equipment Handover & Release
Formal procedure for interaction between maintainer and operator at equipment exchange (shut down and release) and incorporate the following:
• Actions required or taken
• Permits & isolation concerns
• Status / condition of equipment
• Equipment / functional testing after maintenance
• Timely acceptance by operator(s) upon release
• All tests, clean-up, demob, parts & repairables returned.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description:
Formal handover process  in place but not followed.
Equipment often not ready for maintainers.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description:
Formal handover process in use for receiving and delivery of equipment and is mostly followed. 
Could use more detailed acceptance criteria.
Equipment mostly ready for maintainers.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description:
Formal handover process is always followed.
Includes sufficiently detailed procedures for acceptance and/or non-acceptance.
Equipment always ready for maintainers.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Formal sign-off is provided by both operations and maintenance.

questions.title: Schedule Adherence and Break-in Work
questions.question_text:
1. How often does the scheduled work get stopped to perform non-routine work?
2. How are decisions being made as to what scheduled work gets stopped and by whom?
3. Is break-in work being monitored and reviewed to ensure that it is truly urgent work?
questions.context:
Urgent or Unscheduled Work
Priority should be given to performing scheduled work and schedule interruptions must be managed and based on interactions between maintenance and operations.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: There is no formal process in place but there is a balance between urgent and scheduled work. PM or Breakdown work is not specifically prioritized.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Urgent work rarely delays scheduled work. Formal process in place and usually followed. Decisions are made by Operations Supervisors or Maintainers. Breakdown schedule compliance is > 75% Overall schedule compliance is <85%.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: The Maintenance Supervisor decides when the schedule can be interrupted. Formal process is followed with steps to escalate the level of authority or expertise involved in decision making regarding schedule interruption as req. Breakdown schedule compliance >95% Overall schedule compliance >85%.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Breakdown schedule compliance is always 100% Overall schedule compliance >95%.

questions.title: Supervisory Floor Presence
questions.question_text:
1. How often does the supervisor visit tasks during execution?
2. What questions are asked during these visits?
3. Does the supervisor seek out problems and contribute to the solutions?
4. Does supervisor communicate his findings with crews to avoid repetition of failures?
questions.context:
Floor tours
To monitor work execution activities and provide feedback on progress and quality of work
• SHE is observed, questioned and corrected
• Work quality interaction
• Delays recorded
• Actions & contingencies listed
• Improvement opportunities identified.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Expectations are not set, supervisors not visbile in field

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Supervisor spends visible time in field.  SHE issues are addressed

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Supervisor spends visible time in field.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description:
Supervisor hits time in field targets.  Engagement with maintainers and clear communication of failures/problems form crew are raised and resolved.
Autonomy exsists within the crew.

questions.title: Question 33
questions.question_text:
1. Have maintainers received Work Order Completion training?
2. Do maintainers understand the importance of capturing work order history?
3. Have alliance contractors  received Work Order Completion Awareness training?
4. How are new employees being trained in Work Order Completion?
questions.context:
Work Order Completion & Confirmation Training
• Company training should be formally provided to new employees and any necessary contractors, and if necessary refreshed annually 
• Online training material is readily available and linked to the relevant sections of the WMP.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Training is available, but not part of an integrated AM training program.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Training is part of an integrated AM training program with refresher and new hire training reasonably well documented and current for >75% of the teams using the SAP.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Refresher and new hire training is current and documented for >90% of team the teams using the SAP.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Further On the Job Training is used with focus on quality and accurate information.

questions.title: Work History Documentation
questions.question_text:
1. What quality of information is being captured onto work history, and feedback / coaching provided to maintainers?
2. Does the information get captured into the SAP? How?
3. Do RE's use available data for analysis?
4. What percentage of maintenance work orders have history included when Techo'd?
questions.context:
Record Maintenance History
For continuous analysis of failures, the feedback from maintainers into SAP is critical and must include:
• Detailed information on work execution
• Failure modes, causes, parts used and delays recorded    
• Actual time worked (tool-time)

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description:
Failure codes information is captured (Damage, Delay, Cause etc.).
Rarely are task improvements fed back - not always actioned.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description:
History (long text) high quality, failure mode & root cause descriptions easily understood,
Some task improvement feedback - always actioned.
Work Pack completion is reviewed by Supv prior to TECO’ing WOs for quality. 
Measuring points always updated.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description:
Work Performed (long text) history is detailed with all required measurements included prompting regular Asset Tactics improvement. 
Regular task improvement feedback via Notifications & actioned within 28 days.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description:
A process is in place to ensure work history requirements will facilitate reliability-based historical analysis..
Notifications actioned within 7 days.

questions.title: Time Confirmation and Accuracy
questions.question_text:
1. What is the variance between Planned vs. Actual being reported?
2. Are maintainers aware of the importance of capturing accurate times to work orders?
3. Does a time and attendance process drive a behaviour of capturing incorrect actual times to work orders?
4. Is there a process for optimising task lists or standard jobs based on actual times historical information?
questions.context:
Time Confirmation
The accurate capturing of time actually worked is critical. This will allow for:
• The optimisation of planned labour hours on future tasks
• The correct labour cost allocation to work performed
• Must include delay times e.g.: waiting for parts etc.
• Timecard confirmation review process in place.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Maintainers know how to Time Confirm. Maintainer Labour hours are accurately captured on >50% of the work order / operation / tasks. Supervisors completing all Time Confirmation.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Maintainer Labour hours accurately captured on all work order / operation / tasks in the SAP. Confirming time on multiple work orders within 3 days of work completion. Maintainers completing all Time Confirmation to the correct operation.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Maintainer and Contractor Labour hours are captured on all work order / operation / tasks in the SAP. Confirming tool-time within 1 day of work completion. Supervisor reviewing a sample of time confirmations to confirm Plan vs Actual hrs.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Performance against planned hours is monitored and managed. Confirming tool-time same day of completion. Alliance contractors completing Time Confirmation with Supervisor checking.

questions.title: Work Order Closure Timeliness
questions.question_text:
1. How much variance in performance data based on delayed closing of work orders?
2. Are maintainers aware of the consequence of delayed closing on performance metrics?
3. Do supervisors use the metrics to drive behaviour change in closing or work orders?
4. SAP-sites question: How many jobs are TECO'ed with zero (0) hours?
questions.context:
Closing Work Orders
The Closing / confirming process is a critical step in WMP performance metrics and must be done in a timely manner.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Process in place for confirming or closing of WO's but not always followed. Some Work Package completion is quality reviewed by Supervisors prior to TECO’ing WO. Subsequent Notifications not always raised.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: The process is followed and confirmation / closing is carried out within the committed week. Most Work Package completion is quality reviewed by Supervisors prior to TECO’ing WO.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Majority of work orders are TECO’ed within 24hrs of work completion. All Work Package completion is quality reviewed by Supervisors prior to TECO’ing WO. Subsequent Notifications always raised, and raised correctly.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: All of work orders are TECO’ed the same shift as work completion. Work Package completion KPI's published and discussed with teams.

questions.title: Weekly Performance Review Meetings
questions.question_text:
1. Is the schedule (spreadsheet, Gantt chart, etc.) referred to during the review?
2. Is Maintenance & operations related delays/losses discussed?
3. Is action item list up to date with names & dates?
4. Are actions completed in a timely manner?
questions.context:
Meetings - Weekly Review
Weekly plans, schedules and metrics reviewed to identify potential improvement opportunities.
• Participation from both maintenance, operations and service departments such as Warehouse
• Agenda followed and minuted
• Identify what went well
• Identify what did not go well - potential improvements
• Identify what can be done to prevent recurrence of non-conformance.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Ad-hoc informal meeting takes place but focusses on Urgent work.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Plans and schedules are subject to a post execution review at the Weekly Review Meeting. Focus is on Standard Metrics.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Failure to meet targets is analysed, specific causes identified and action plans implemented with owners allocated for each action. >80% of actions closed out each week.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: All potential WMP system improvements are raised formally with the Asset Management team for action.

questions.title: Daily 24-Hour Work Review Process
questions.question_text:
1. Work order completion is reviewed? Do maintainers attend these sessions?
2. At the 24 hr review, is the following done: Any PM not scheduled needs to be questioned. Any Corrective needs to be questioned. Did it need to be done straight away or could it have been scheduled?
Is the failure mode captured in the equipment PM?
If Yes, Do we need to complete an RCA, PMO on the strategy applied? Is there an action plan?
3. Is action item list up to date with names & dates?
4. Are actions completed in a timely manner?
questions.context:
Meetings - 24-hour daily review
Daily Review to identify potential improvement opportunities
• Agenda followed and minuted
• Identify what went well
• Identify what did not go well
• Identify what can be done to prevent recurrence of non-conformances
• Discuss any  Notifications raised or whether or not a Noti is required for something

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: A review takes place and only focuses on breakdowns. There is no agenda. The need for improvements to Tactics and Work Packs not discussed.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Work order completion is reviewed in morning meetings, with an agenda and action plan produced. The review is done at the daily KPI board and focusses on schedule non- conformances. People trust the KPI's are an accurate reflection.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: The team discuss the need for Tactics reviews or RCA's as a result of the previous 24hrs equipment, operations and work management performance.  Notifications are raised properly if required.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Management provides support to ensure action plan is effective. This support structure is clearly defined and understood by all.

questions.title: KPI Visibility and Understanding
questions.question_text:
1. Are metrics posted and up to date?
2. Are metrics understood by all?
- Are appropriate metrics in place to measure effectiveness of the work management process?
- Are the metrics accessible to all relevant personnel and stakeholders?
- Are metrics posted and up to date?
- Do the metrics include quality and cost performance?
3. Are new metrics being rolled out on a regular basis?
questions.context:
KPI data
Appropriate metrics must be in place to measure effectiveness of process:
• Metrics developed 
• Posted in appropriate work areas
• Utilised to drive behaviour change
• Review of overdue statutory requirements

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: KPIs are clearly understood and communicated. Maintenance team have a weekly KPI discussion.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Management decisions are made based on KPI performance. The KPI system is easily accessible by maintainers and influences daily work execution.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Reliability team analyse KPIs and feed this into DE activities, tactics development activities. Asset Management Metrics and area KPI's are reviewed with all personnel.

questions.title: Reliability Integration and Feedback
questions.question_text:
1. How is repetitive failures reported to the Reliability Group?
2. Does the Reliability group have access to the KPI's and WM system?
3. Where are all the reported findings /  recommendation captured - are the teams using Notifications?
4. How does the information get reported back to the maintenance teams?
questions.context:
Work Management Feedback to / Inclusion of Reliability Group
Interaction between the WMP and the Reliability Processes (Defect Elimination & Asset Strategy & Tactics) is crucial and must include:
• Loss Analysis data
• Repetitive failures occurrences (chronic/systemic)
• Changes in Tactics
• Changes in operating conditions
• Improvements or recommendations
• Cost over-runs

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Process consists of informal discussions with very little feedback to the maintenance team.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Process consists of informal discussions which are not always recorded. Some feedback on critical equipment and incidents takes place.  Notifications sometimes raised.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Process consists of formal discussions which are recorded via meeting minutes.Notifications raised as required and resultant ATD (Asset Tactics Development) and reviews are conducted on Critical systems or equipment.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Reported findings become part of the DE process and the drumbeat ATD process on all systems and equipment.

questions.title: Operational Loss Monitoring Systems
questions.question_text:
1. Is there an automated system to capture Operation loss,
2. Is the system covering all areas of Operation,
3. Are failure modes and causes captured?
questions.context:
Operation Loss Monitoring
A process exists to capture Operation losses and equipment downtime / delays

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Process to capture Operation losses is not clear. Operation losses and delays are captured inconsistently are reported word of mouth or on timecards or shift logs for entry into a database.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Operation losses and delays are captured using an automated system, but data is not always accurate or easily accessible for data analysis.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description:
Operation losses and delays are captured using an automated system and the data is always accurate and easily accessible for data analysis. Close to 80% of maintenance related Operation losses have an associated workorder in the
SAP (or AMS)

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description:
Operation losses and delays are captured using an automated system and the data is always accurate and easily accessible for data analysis. Close to 95% of maintenance related Operation losses have an associated workorder in the
SAP (or AMS).

questions.title: Data Sources for Defect Identification
questions.question_text:
1. Are all Operation areas accounted for?
2. Are all sources utilised?
3. What data sources are used?
4. What are the DE data sources in use at site?
questions.context:
Data Sources for Defect Identification
Defects are identified through the analysis of various sources of data. 
Potential data sources include:
• Operation Performance data
• Maintenance History / Work Order data
• Logbook data
• Visual Work Place.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No clear process for identifying defects. Defects are identified ad hoc mostly from gut feel.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Defects identified through data analysis of one key source.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Defects identified through data analysis of several key sources.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Defects identified through data analysis of all key sources for all Operation processes.

questions.title: Defect Identification Through Observations
questions.question_text: 1. Are observations made by technicians, maintainers and operators used to identify defects during execution of work?
questions.context:
Observations Leading to Defect Identification
A process is in place to capture defects through observations and escalate into DE process (as appropriate)
Sources of observation data:
• Direct observation
• Interviews
• Safety interactions
• Floor Tours / Task Analysis.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No clear process in place to capture defects through observations. Defects from observations are identified through various sources but  not captured in a central location.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Most defects from observations are captured in a central location.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: All defects from observations are captured in a central location.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Defects through observations are captured on a defect register

questions.title: Incident Investigation for Defect Identification
questions.question_text:
1. Are defects identified using incident reports?
2. What RCA tools are used in incident investigation?
3. How are defects captured from your SHE system transferred to the defect register?
questions.context:
Incident Investigations
A process exists to capture defects identified by incident investigations.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: There is no clear progress or an informal process to capture defects through incidents.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Defects for incidents are captured in a central location for review.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Defects from incidents are captured in the central defect register. Cross- functional teams are used to identify the root cause(s) and required corrective actions for all major incidents.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description:
Defects from incidents are captured in the central defect register. Cross- functional teams are used to identify the root cause(s) and required corrective actions for all major incidents.
Sound reliability engineering judgement is applied in all cases, ensuring that the corrective actions are based on data
and facts.

questions.title: Defect Assessment and Prioritization
questions.question_text:
1. Does the Defect Register identify the value of each potential defect in monetary terms?
2. What models/processes are applied to assessing/prioritising defects?
3. Do you have triggers that require the site to automatically commence an RCA?
4. Is Safety, Health, and Environment (SHE) considered?
5. Is reputation considered?
questions.context:
Assess and Prioritise Defects
Defects are assessed and prioritised by quantifying the risk and value of eliminating the defect.
Estimates must be made for the following factors:
• Value of eliminating the defect
• Risk the defect poses to the business
• Difficulty in eliminating the defect
• Cost to eliminate defect.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: lassifying

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Defect are assessed based on some of the factors listed but not all.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Defects are prioritized using a approved Company risk/value matrix.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Proactive Defect Elemination - Protential Defects are prioritized using a approved Company risk/value matrix.

questions.title: Defect Register Scope and Integration
questions.question_text: Does the Defect Register include other business improvement initiatives?
questions.context:
Defect Register
A Defect Register is used to capture all potential defect projects. This facilitates the prioritisation of defects and the effective allocation of resources.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: The defect register does not exist or is an informal and uncontrolled document.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: A formal defect register is setup but does not include all potential projects.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: The central defect register is established and aligned with the current Reliability Improvement system.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: The central defect register is established and is fully  integrated with the current Business  Improvement system.

questions.title: Analysis Process Selection and Triggers
questions.question_text:
1. Are  triggers defined/documented for various levels of loss analysis, depending on the severity/impact of the loss?
2. Is a formalised process implemented for front- line personnel to conduct basic RCA's (e.g. 5- why, etc.)?
3. Is a formalised process implemented for Reliability engineers or maintenance/ops specialists to conduct more complex RCAs for significant/complex losses?
4. Are complex RCA's are managed as projects?
5. Is a formalised process implemented for Reliability engineers or maintenance/ops specialists to conduct an annual/bi-annual review of significant business losses or accumulating losses not picked up at individual loss event?
questions.context:
Selection of Process
A decision is made as to whether a team-based approach is necessary or if the defect can be assigned to an individual to "just do it". 
There are agreed triggers to initiate the defect elimination process

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description:
Ad-hoc with no specific process for methodology selection.
No or Informal criteria used at DE Management Team meetings.
Depends on who is at the meeting.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description:
Formal criteria exists but not always followed by the DE Management Team.
Does not align with existing business processes.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description:
Formal criteria always followed by the DE Management Team.
Aligns with existing business processes.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Formal criteria always followed by the DE Management Team. Intetgrated with existing business processes.

questions.title: DE Team Selection and Resourcing
questions.question_text: Is there attendance at Defect Elimination team meetings?
questions.context:
DE Team Selection.
Teams are selected to work on Defect Elimination projects. The DE Management team must ensure the team is sufficiently resourced.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No specific process for selection of teams or DE teams are selected outside of the DE Management Team usually within a department.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: DE teams are approved by the DE Management Team.  Teams are not always sufficiently resourced.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: DE teams are sufficiently resourced but not always cross-functional.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: DE Teams are cross functional and involve all required skill sets.

questions.title: RCA Method Training and Capability
questions.question_text: Are there personnel trained in each of the different tools available?
questions.context:
Root Cause Analysis (RCA)  Methods
Multiple Root Cause Analysis (RCA) methods are made available to the DE Team and are personnel trained in their use.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description:
No RCA methods used.
The business has a few people capable of using ad hoc problem-solving tools.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: The business has a few people trained in facilitating RCA methods (5-Whys, Cause-and-Effect/ Structure Tree, Apollo RCA, TapRooT, KT).

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: The business has a formal set of RCA methods and has cross functional personnel identified and trained in their use.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: A process is in place where the business can select from many areas to choose the best tool and facilitator to address the defect.

questions.title: RCA Method Selection Criteria
questions.question_text:
1. Is there criteria for what tool or technique will be used?
2. Is the criteria based on actual or potential impact to the business?
questions.context:
Selection of RCA method
There are many methods and processes available to assist in the identification of the root causes of a defect.
The specific method chosen will depend on a number of factors:
• Problem complexity
• Risk defect poses
• Problem Dimensions
• If a team is being used.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Limited RCA methods are used. Selection of a tool to determine root cause is left up to the team or individual.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Team or individual selects the RCA method they are most familiar with.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: A Reliability Engineer or team leader selects the RCA method to be used based on his / her judgment.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: There is a clear procedure for selecting the RCA method to be used and the team make up is aligned with this.

questions.title: Problem Statement and Team Charter Developmen
questions.question_text: Are team charters developed including problem statements?
questions.context:
Problem Statement
A Team Charter is developed for each DE Team that includes a clear problem statement.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No clear problem statement or team charter. Only the concept has been explained to the team.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Only the Facilitator develops the problem statement and Team charter.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: The Facilitator puts the problem statement and charter together with the Team.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: The Facilitator puts the problem statement and charter together with the Team and it is understood and communicated to the key stakeholders.

questions.title: Question 17
questions.question_text: How many teams are active and are they comprised of more than just maintenance personnel?
questions.context:
Team Composition
Key stakeholders are represented in the Defect Elimination Team to provide input into the problem and solution analysis? Teams should include roles such as:
• Facilitator
• Team Leader
• Reliability Engineer
• Team Members (representing areas effected).

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Team make up is not considered or team members are chosen based on availability.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Teams are made up of only people that are the most technically knowledgeable of the defect.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: There is a cross functional team that represents what's effected by the defect, but only includes supervisors and above.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: The DE Management Team strives to involve as many people as possible throughout the organization to make DE a normal daily activity, and the teams include hourly personnel as needed.

questions.title: Root Cause Action Development
questions.question_text: Are the teams always focused on getting to the root cause.
questions.context:
Identify potential actions
Are all potential solutions and actions evaluated by the responsible DE Team or individual and are they formally documented?
Solutions and actions have to address the root causes as well as any contributing factors.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description:
No actions identified.
Some actions identified but do not address the root causes.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Actions identified address the root cause.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Actions  identified address root cause as well as any contributing factors.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Actions take into account both short and long term time frames for the overall benefit of the business.

questions.title: Action Evaluation and Approval
questions.question_text:
1. Does the owner of the relevant cost centre get to sign off on the actions?
2. Is the evaluation methodology aligned with the site's Edge evaluation method?
questions.context:
Evaluation of potential actions
All potential actions are evaluated against specific criteria. Actions should be evaluated in terms of:
• Addressing the root cause
• SHE Implications
• Cost to implement
• Ease of implementation.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description:
No evaluation of potential actions is made.
Potential actions are discussed, but not evaluated against any specific criteria.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Potential actions are informally evaluated against some of the criteria.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Potential actions are formally evaluated against most of the criteria by the DE Team.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Potential actions are formally evaluated against all of the criteria with help from key stakeholders.

questions.title: Action Plan Development
questions.context:
Action Plan
Detailed action plans developed with clear accountability.
 Action plans should include:
• Actions
• Accountability
• Targets & deliverables
• Status.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No action plans in place or the action plans are non-specific and hard to measure.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: The action plans are aligned with the target areas but need more details

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: The action plans include required actions, accountability, and completion dates.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: The action plans include benefit targets and deliverables for the overall success of the business.

questions.title: Success Measurement Planning
questions.question_text:
1. Is the criteria for success clearly defined and understood by the team and management?
2. Do the KPIs both help to track and manage project progress and ultimately whether or not the project goals were achieved?
questions.context:
Establish a measurement plan.
A measurement plan is in place that includes a baseline with appropriate measures / KPI and targets.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No plan in place or the plan does not  measure the effectiveness of the approved actions.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: The plan measures the effectiveness of most of the approved actions.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: An accurate baseline has been established with process indicators and KPIs that reflect the target areas.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: An accurate baseline has been established with process indicators and KPIs that reflect the target areas and are a mixture of leading and lagging KPI's.

questions.title: Action Approval Process
questions.question_text: Is there a clearly defined process that is documented?
questions.context:
Approval
Proper approval is obtained for all actions prior to implementation (i.e.: change management).

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No approval procedure in place or approval is informal and inconsistent. Change management requirements are never considered.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Written approval is usually obtained as required from stakeholders. Change management requirements not always considered.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Approval is always obtained and any necessary change management requirements are always completed before implementing the improvement.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: The approval process includes a high level review of all findings and actions by the DE management Team.

questions.title: Action Accountability Management
questions.question_text: Does management understand the actions assigned to team members that report to them?
questions.context:
Accountability
Clear accountabilities are established for the completion of the action plan and is it syndicated with management. 
Accountabilities to include:
• Project management
• Action completion
• Action management
• Cost management
• Monitoring progress.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No clear accountabilities are established or accountability is only discussed at the DE Management Team Meeting.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Accountability is understood by DE Team members and has been documented. Actions are often not managed and completed as planned.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Site Leaders regularly monitor the progress of DE Team members on the action plan, most actions are managed and completed as planned.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Site Leaders regularly monitor the progress of DE Team members and all actions are managed and completed as planned.

questions.title: Action Progress Review
questions.question_text:
Are current projects on track?
2. Is allowance made for people to complete their DE actions as well as their other work?
questions.context:
Action close out
The DE Team's actions and progress reviewed at the monthly DE Management Team meeting. Any slippage in actions must be addressed through additional resources, tools or collaboration.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description:
No review is made of the actions and progress of the individual DE Teams.
The action plan is reviewed sometimes but is inconsistent.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: The action plan is regularly reviewed but team pushes out many actions.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: The action plan is regularly reviewed and there is a focus on meeting the deadlines.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: The action plan is regularly reviewed and there is always a plan put in place to bring actions back onto schedule with support from Site Leaders.

questions.title: Action Progress Tracking
questions.question_text:
1. Is there a DE action register for team based activities?
2. Are larger DE activities formally managed as Projects?
3. Are the DE Teams using the DE register to help track their projects?
questions.context:
Tracking Progress
 DE Team progress is tracked using various documents?
• Meeting Minutes
• Who Does What When List (Actions Log)
• Defect Register.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description:
DE Team progress is not updated.
An informal action log is updated infrequently.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: An informal action log is updated with action plan progress weekly and distributed to team members and site leaders as requested.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: The defect register is updated with action plan progress once a week along with the meeting minutes.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: The defect register is continuously kept up to date with all changes and is accessible to all site leaders and stakeholders.

questions.title: Loss Prevention and Continuous Learning System
questions.question_text:
Has a business process been implemented which defines the following:
• A formalised register/tracker is in place to monitor action status from initiation to closure?
• A post-completion audit is defined to validate the effectiveness of defect elimination actions?
daily/weekly/monthly/annual loss reporting, review and analysis?
• A process is defined to share the learnings across the company but also to vendors and wider industry?
questions.context:
Business process for defect elimination


An effective business process should be defined for defect elimination.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No approval procedure in place or a basic ad-hoc process is in place but it is not documented.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: A documented process is implemented which covers most items listed under "Focus Questions".

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: A documented process is implemented which covers all items listed under "Focus Questions". No formal audit process in place to audit compliance and effectiveness.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: A documented process is implemented which covers all items listed under "Focus Questions". Compliance and effectiveness is audited at least annually.

questions.title: DE Management Review Process
questions.question_text:
1. Does the agenda for the DE Management Team meeting include time for review of past projects?
2. Does the DE Management Team's review of current projects focus on KPI's and targets?
questions.context:
DE Management Review
The DE Teams should be regularly reporting progress back through to the DE Management Team.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No review takes place or there are informal reviews of the measures but no updates from the DE Teams.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: The DE Teams provide an update on progress at the Monthly DE Management Team Meeting. Reporting tends to be developed last minute.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: The DE Teams update the DE Register prior to the DE Management Teams monthly meeting. DE Management Team reviews the DE Register at each meeting looking for major non-conformances to projects.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: DE Management Team gives specific feedback to DE teams on what is going well and where they could improve the results shown in the KPIs and measures.

questions.title: Project Sustainability Monitoring
questions.question_text:
1. Are any projects completed in the past year still monitored for sustainability?
2. Are there ever any long term KPI's allocated to DE projects?
questions.context:
Sustainability
The long-term sustainability actions are assured through scheduled reviews of past DE projects.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description:
Projects results are not sustained.
Sometimes DE Teams or leaders will review trends of project targets against expected KPIs.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: The DE Management Team reviews completed DE Projects on an ad-hoc basis.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Completed DE projects are monitored according to the measurement plan by a DE Team member or accountable person.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Results are reported to the DE Management team monthly and corrective actions taken for negative trends.

questions.title: Outcome Communication and Sharing
questions.question_text: Is there much awareness about the successful outcome of DE projects throughout the organization?
questions.context:
Outcomes
The outcomes of the DE Project are updated in the Defect Register and are the outcomes syndicated?

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No updates are made of the DE Team's projects or the main source of information about the DE Project is from the Team leader.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: The outcomes of the DE Project are updated in the Defect Register.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: The outcomes of the DE Project are communicated across the site.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: The outcomes of the DE Project are communicated across the site. The outcomes of the DE Project are made available to other Company sites

questions.title: Asset Criticality Assessment
questions.question_text:
1. Are supervisors, planners and technicians aware of the criticality ranking of equipment or systems?
2. Is criticality ranking updated as new changes are made to tactics?
3. Is criticality ranking updated as operational requirements change?
questions.context:
Asset Criticality
Criticality Analysis is important for determining where to focus Asset Tactic Development activities.  Criticality is based on consequence and likelihood.  Categories may include:
• Safety, Health & Environmental
• Costs
• Operational.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: There is no criticality analysis of systems or equipment or there has been a criticality analysis at the system level only for all assets.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: There has been a criticality analysis at the physical asset or item level and ranking scores given to critical assets.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Asset Criticality ranking is based on the Company Asset Criticality Guideline.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Asset criticality ranking is always used when reviewing or developing asset tactics.

questions.title: Risk Management Integration
questions.question_text:
1. Are supervisors, planners and coordinators aware of the Company Enterprise Risk Management Framework and Appetite?
2. Is Risk rating updated as new changes are made to tactics? Is this communicated to site leadership?
3. Is Risk rating updated as operational requirements change?
questions.context:
Risk Management 
It is important for determining where to focus Asset Tactic Development activities. Risk Management is based on consequence and likelihood utilising the Company Enterprise Risk Management Framework and Appetite.
Categories may include:
• Safety & Environmental
• Costs
• Operation.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: There has been no criticality analysis based on established risk management processes for all assets.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: There has been a risk analysis at the physical asset or item level and ranking scores given to critical assets.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Risk rankings are based on the Company Enterprise Risk Management Framework and Appetite. All approved asset criticality ranking are recorded in a central database and captured in SAP.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Risk rankings are based on the Company Enterprise Risk Management Framework and Appetite. All Material Risks (Level 5 and Level 6) have established Asset Tactic Development activities incorporated into risk treatment plans.

questions.title: Tactics Development Database
questions.question_text:
1. Does the database have a logical hierarchy of equipment with a breakdown structure for critical equipment?
2. Does the database contain a listing of common failure modes?
questions.context:
Asset Tactic Development Database
A database is important to document analysis and track decision making history. Some other functions of a database are:
• Developing equipment hierarchies & structures
• Statistical Analysis
• Asset Tactic Development database containing common failure mechanisms etc.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No database used only Excel Spreadsheets are used.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: A relational database is used such as Access.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: A stand-alone software product is used with statistical analysis functions by Above Rail and Non-rail - IronMan

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: A stand-alone software product is used for all of Company with statistical analysis functions. Database is linked to SAP (or AMS).

questions.title: Tactics Review Process
questions.question_text:
1. Is there evidence of tactics review sessions?
2. Are the triggers for review documented?
3. Does the Reliability group report on reviews that have been completed?
questions.context:
Review of Tactics
A process should be in place which will trigger a re-evaluation of tactics.  Triggers for re-evaluation can include:
• Time-Based
• Poor Performance
• Change in conditions
• Defect Elimination
• Change in operating context.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: There is no evidence of any  review of Tactics or an ad-hoc review of tactics is made periodically for some equipment.  Triggers are normally incidents or poor equipment performance.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Most triggered reviews are performed based on time, feedback from maintenance of from incident investigation.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Triggers are set for review of critical assets. Triggered reviews are performed based numerious operational performance measures.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: There is a comprehensive plan for the review of tactics. It is embedded in how we do business and is triggered by technical advances, performance & operating context.

questions.title: Team-Based Tactics Development
questions.question_text:
1. Are there agendas and action plans available?
2.  Have the recommendations made by previous teams actually made it into the SAP/CMMS system?
questions.context:
Team-Based Tactics Development
A team-based approach to Asset Tactic Development will improve the effectiveness of the overall program.  Teams are normally involved in the development & implementation steps:
• Asset Tactic Development analysis
• Data gathering
• Field Validation.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Team based tactics development never or rarely used.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Formal Teams exist with goals and action plans.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Teams are cross-functional (Maintenance, Reliability, Operations, Technical) and include OEM representatives where needed.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Cross site teams are encouraged and effectively complete projects. Share tactics with and adapt tactics from other sites.

questions.title: Project Selection and Prioritization
questions.question_text:
1. Does a prioritized list exist?
2. Does each program have clearly defined boundaries for analysis?
3. Are projects normally of short duration and frequent rather than large and intermittent?
questions.context:
Selection of Projects
Tactics development projects are prioritised and selected based on specific criteria:
• Criticality
• Performance
• Value.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No Tactics Development projects are planned or a list exists of Tactics development  projects with limited criteria for prioritization.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Projects are prioritized utilizing criticality ranking and other criteria.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Tactics Development projects are approved through a management selection process.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Management process explicitly includes resourcing of the selected projects.

questions.title: Decision History Documentation
questions.question_text: Can the organization demonstrate how critical tasks or intervals were determined?
questions.context:
Decision History
It is important to record the decision-making history behind tasks and intervals used in a maintenance strategy.  This will facilitate:
• Review and updating of tactics
• Identifying gaps in information needs.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: Asset Tactic Development decision making history is not recorded or Asset Tactic Development information is documented but not in a Asset Tactic Development database.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: RCM,FMEA, PMO task type and decision logic captured in a Asset Tactic Development database at an Asset level.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: All changes or updates to tactics information is recorded in a Asset Tactic Development database at the component level for all critical assets.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: All changes or updates to tactics decisions are recorded in the Asset Tactic Development database component level.

questions.title: Critical Equipment Tactics Validation
questions.question_text:
1. Can critical tasks in CMMS be found in the Asset Tactic Development database?
2.  Are critical tasks derived from a FMECA/RCM analysis?
questions.context:
Asset Tactic Development-Critical Equipment Tactics
Tasks and associated intervals recorded in a Tactics database should reflect the actual maintenance strategies in use:
• Tasks (and intervals) for critical equipment should exist in the Asset Tactic Development database
• Tasks for critical equipment should have had some level of FMECA/RCM analysis.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: There is no database or tasks and intervals used in the CMMS system reflect those in the Tactics Database.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: >50% of tasks performed for critical equipment exist in tactics database.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: 100% of tasks performed for critical equipment are exist in tactics database.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: All new assets/equipment and/or acquired assets/equipment have had formal Asset Tactic Development analysis completed for tasks and intervals for critical assets/equipment.

questions.title: Task Documentation Standards
questions.question_text:
1. Do service sheets have a standard template?
2. Are inspection tasks clearly defined as to what is considered acceptable or not?
3. Are the tasks easily understood?
4. Are critical tasks emphasized in some way?
questions.context:
Document Design
Tasks effectiveness is influenced in how they are presented as service sheets or other such documentation. Documentation guidelines should exist as:
• Standard templates
• Standard terminology
• Clearly defined fields for feedback
• Methods of emphasis.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: No standard documentation used or Service sheets / work instructions use a standard template.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: Tasks are written taking into consideration the expected trades experience levels.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Tasks are written using a standard terminology.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Document Design guidelines are used for terminology, photo, reference material, etc.

questions.title: Field Validation Process
questions.question_text:
1. Is there a form to validate new service sheets or tasks?
2. Have all safety considerations considered when new tasks are implemented?
questions.context:
Field Validation
First time execution of a changed or newly created tactic must be evaluated in the field. Not validating tasks in the field will lead to ineffective tactics and a lack of confidence in the entire program.
Field validation should focus on ensuring:
• Safety, Ergonomic or Environmental issues resolved
• Proper sequencing of tasks
• Equipment access issues
• Identify tools and parts requirements
• Identify training needs.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: There is no process to field validate new tasks or service sheets or some Tasks are validated ad hoc in the field after inclusion in CMMS system.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: New tasks are clearly identified and are field validated by maintainers.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
rating_scales.description: Complex tasks are field validated by maintainers and a reliability engineer.

rating_scales.name: Optimised
rating_scales.description: Complex Field Validation is part of Change Management Procedures.

questions.title: Task Packaging and Integration
questions.question_text:
1. Is there a task packaging function for the Asset Tactic Development database used?
2.  Do tasks have an actual interval less than the derived interval from the FMECA/RCM/Reverse RCM/PMO analysis?
questions.context:
Task Packaging
Tasks must integrate with the current maintenance program.  Careful consideration must be taken to how tasks are packaged and scheduled in the maintenance program.

rating_scales.name: Reactive
rating_scales.description: New tasks or service sheets are integrated into the CMMS without much consideration for the overall maintenance program. Output of task/service sheet development is left up to others to be incorporated into maintenance program.

rating_scales.name: Planned
rating_scales.description: A documented process exists for effective task packaging responsibilities are clearly defined in a RACI but it's not always followed.

rating_scales.name: Proactive
